div.p: This sub-element is found in BIOGRAPHY EDUCATION . It captures all degrees (BA, MA, PhD), diplomas, certificates, etc. received by the entry subject. It goes around the name of the degree, and has one optional attribute, REG, which allows you to express the degree in a standard way if you have been unable to do so in your prose. (Oxford gives a D.Phil. where others give a PhD, which would be the REG form.)

div.codeblock: May 1968 HB received a <DEGREE>BA</DEGREE> from Cambridge University.
May 1968 HB received an <DEGREE>Honours BA in English</DEGREE> from Cambridge University.

div.p: Answer: No, it means Companion of the British Empire. If given in recognition of achievements in literature, save it for the RECOGNITION and RECOGNITIONNAME elements in the WRITING subset. If given for other life achievements, then record the information in the appropriate chronological place in BIOGRAPHY tags, within the OCCUPATION or POLITICS element.
Question: Should an honorary degree go in Education?
Answer: No; it is a form of recognition and should be tagged in WRITING as RECOGNITION.
Question: My writer attended a university before it granted degrees to women; however, she placed first in her class. How do I mark this?
Answer: Put a DEGREE tag around whatever phrase in the sentence comes closest to describing a certificate or whatever.
